content.description: Sit start at base of vertical crack in the prominent arete. Stand up using arete and move feet up crack. Reach left hand to slopey crimp halfway up. Move feet higher up crack until the right foot reaches the "X" created by the intersecting horizontal crack. Make a big reach to the ledge. Pull over ledge to top-out.
content.protection: 2-3 pads, spotter on right side of arete.
content.location: Right end of slab side facing uphill.

content.description: Sit start with both hands crossed on arete. Lean hard right, stand up and reach right to a good hold. Establish feet on overhanging side and work to top using the arete on left and small edges on right. Note: The large backwards "C"-shaped flake is out! It is unstable and also far too easy. Also, the large arcing shelf to the right is not to be used for feet. An extra small pad is necessary to cover the pointed rock in the landing zone.
content.location: Overhanging left-most arete on side facing west (JBL).

content.description: Start as for Vision of the Victors. After reaching the first lip, move right into corner crack formed by large ramp. Stem the corner to reach higher up the crack to a monster jug, then pull up onto the ramp. Stand up and reach to lip at the tallest section of the boulder. Mantle for top-out.
content.location: Left arete of side facing JBL.

content.description: Good movement on big holds, if only it was longer! Sit start with hands matched on lowest left-rising corner. Stand up and follow obvious C-shaped corner to top.
content.location: Right end of side facing downhill.

content.description: Stand start - match hands on crimp behind bulge, right foot on rail beneath bulge, left foot hooked around arete. Reach up arete, match feet on rail, then step far right to a good hold. Swing weight right, then work straight up arete, keeping feet only on the slab.
content.location: Leftmost arete of slab side facing uphill.

content.description: A large, secluded boulder with climbing on three sides with an easy walk-off, including two superb routes of completely different style.
